replies.author: @ZaavanMusic
replies.text: Control and abuse are two different things. I bet you don‚Äôt have kids because if you did you wouldn‚Äôt be saying such a wild statement. Especially without further explanation of your position. I control what my kid watches, eats, when they sleep, brush their teeth, etc. because they need to form good habits and without that constant guidance the habits won‚Äôt carry over into them being a teenager or an adult.

replies.author: @Staenhus
@76678-m
replies.text: Thank you! I was thinking the same thing, and as much as I enjoy this channel, I don‚Äôt think Olurinatti gave it the attention it deserves. When violent criminals talk about the abuse they‚Äôve suffered as children, people frequently mock it and write it off as ‚Äúmaking excuses‚Äù This just reinforces the whole idea that upbringing, environment, etc., have no bearing on people‚Äôs behavior and that our society is absolved from any responsibility in creating the very monsters it claims it wants to protect us from. We need to start recognizing violent, harmful behavior as the product of our society and environment as much as it is a moral failing.

replies.author: @76678-m
replies.text:
@kayjayhayI‚Äôm certainly not an expert, but the role entitlement plays sounds right. I still don‚Äôt see the need to write the abuser‚Äôs claims of his own abuse off, though. Perhaps along with his sense of entitlement, his abuse also played a role in his behavior. And even if he is a manipulator, that doesn‚Äôt mean his claims of abuse are wrong or they had no impact on his behavior. 

I think the point I really want to drive home is that we need to stop seeing evil people as one dimensional, storybook villains who simply wake up one day and choose violence. They are, at least partially, the products of their environments ‚Äî their societies, families, etc,. ‚Äî as well as their mental health. That‚Äôs not to say they have no control over their behavior, or that it doesn‚Äôt deserve condemnation, but that control is hindered by their environment and mental health. Such environments promote toxic masculinity ‚Äî eg., senses of entitlement and unhealthy ways of expressing anger ‚Äî that facilite abuse against women, trans people, and men themselves. We need to focus more on taking proactive steps towards combatting the environmental/mental health factors that help cause this violence as well as working to rehabilitate these individuals, even if they are serving life sentences.

replies.author: @76678-m
@76678-m
replies.text: @kayjayhay same to you! I‚Äôm glad we realized we‚Äôre on the same page and apologize if I came off as overly argumentative at the beginning.

author: @LalaDepala_00
text:
Girl, my ex was a "redpiller". Big fan of Andrew Tate, etc.

When we got together he wasn't as open about these things. It started a couple months into the relationship.

He was talking down on women every single day. Every bad thing in this world was the fault of women. Every woman was a w----, etc. 

I was loyal (I am traditional, still live at home, etc) but he was still always angry. He always assumed I was cheating on him. Guess what? I found out he cheated on me four times.

These men are genuinely dangerous. They hold women to extremely high standards, but never themselves. You can be as perfect as possible - they will still hate you. I feel sorry for the woman who is in his life right now. 

I genuinely wouldn't be surprised if he ends up killing someone. That was the level of anger he had towards women.

author: @laurabXOTWOD
text: I want to be a "good Leftist" but as the victim of someone currently serving 10 life sentences that doesn't believe he could be reformed its difficult for me to be fully onboard with abolishion. I totally agree a lot of crime could be avoided with the proper programs and services, but i personally believe there will always be some, albeit a fairly small percentage of incarcerated prisoners, that are just evil and will always do evil things if allowed the freedom to do so, and I just don't see how that could work with abolishing prisons. I agree police don't offer much protection to most people, especially people of colour, but in my case there is no doubt in my mind that theres multiple women walking around happy and unraped because hes locked up, and sadly I think there will always be some like him. He wasn't in poverty, he had no documented mental health issues or drug addictions, he had a wife who loved him so much she declared to the press she was going to stay with him, even after he changed his plea to guily mid trial and friends who defended him by saying he couldn't do what he did because he had no trouble getting girls in the clubs, he was just an evil man who got off on making strangers he dragged off the street think they were about to die, im just not sure what kind of government program could prevent him or those like him from doing what they want to do

Its so crazy that after moving to a country, creating some stability there, having a child whose accustomed to that place, that she'd have reasons to stay in that country other than her husband... give me a break. üôÑ Just because the marriage fails doesn't mean she wants to disassemble the rest of her life in the US.

author: @GrayYeonWannabe
text: this reminds me of a dude i dated back when i was 18/19 and he was 29/30. horribly mistreated by his father, his mother didn't understand or care to intervene and would tell his father when he misbehaved, leading to horrific corporal punishment. he internalized that as punishment being the man's role in a relationship and women being the perpetrators of emotional harm, to which men only had their physicality to defend against. he was a deeply hurt man, and no one in his life had given him the chance to change (early on, i mean. nothing i could have done would have 'saved' him). i do hope he was able to break the cycle of abuse, but seeing as he stalked me for three years, i highly doubt it. the saddest part is that if you did get to know him (which i do not recommend), you could tell there was still that little hurting child within him. people aren't born monsters, they're produced.

replies.author: @GrayYeonWannabe
replies.text: and when he was a 19yo (maybe 20? idr, it's been a decade since i met him) he committed a felony robbery. prison only further ingrained his beliefs about violence. truly tragic. only because i made it out alive (by the skin of my teeth) can i even reflect on this & give him back the humanity so many others denied to him. it took a decade, but my experiences with him turned out to be integral to my understanding of how our society produces monsters & the true meaning of prison abolition. thanks as always for the gr8 vid

author: @FM-uz6jn
text: I‚Ä¶ was not mentally ready to listen to him speaking like this. It made me blank out for a second and have a survivor moment, but I will try to circle back when I can.

author: @fallingdream
text: I didn't comment on this right away because I needed time to process what happened. This video appeared in my reccs the day after I prevented a matricide. I was already an abolitionist, and the experience did not shake my convictions, in fact it strengthened them, but this video perfectly put into words why. It didn't happen in a vacuum. The details, that I won't go into because I'm not here to trauma dump, are deeply misogynist and dis/ableist in nature, which to me reaffirms that to prevent violence we need to build communities that are resistant to bigotry and structural inequity. Thank you for putting it into plain words, I'm not always the best communicator and this video has been really helpful in explaining to others why yes, even after that, I'm still an abolitionist, and no, that does not mean I think this individual should be let wander around and hurt people, and no that's not a contradiction.

author: @DiaryofaDitchWitch
text:
My very first Sociology & Politics module in university in Ireland, aka Soc & Pol 101, taught me two things: 1. It cost ‚Ç¨90k/yr to keep one person in jail and 2. Recidivism rates were at something like 96%.

And from experience I knew that once inside, most criminals learn how to do crime better.

We were having the worst recession of my lifetime at the time. I had to drop out of that uni course because my funding was cut in the budget that year, and there was a housing crisis shaping up.

It occurred to me how I'd have a guaranteed bed and three square meals if I did some crime. Go were the funding is. 

But I didn't. I went protesting instead.

author: @mellowthm566
text:
So much this. DV is a always an issue of ideology. Not necessarily a bigotry but a fundamental belief that power justifies oppression, a la might makes right. The bigotry is the story of why your target deserves violence and you deserve power. They're a ideological pair. Misogyny is the two for one combo that no one ordered, it was already cooking.

And all that is hard to untangle in a oppressive system with ever present examples reinforcing ideologies that justify extraction of needs through the suffering of others. And then reinforcing the supporting ideologies of the extraction. Under the logic of " look i deserve all this power because they cower... And they cower cause I hurt them which proves my power"ü§¢. And it's validated because violence is a  material power that is treated as morally justifying. A violence of merit.

Ughh those recordings are vile

text: I think it's also important to recognize that his case was very clearly racially motivated. He made a clear empahisis multiple times to the fact that she was filipino. He constantly brought that up as well as bringing up her status as an immigrant. People do not see immigrants, especially those from third world countries as real people. That's why we're so fetishized and there are so many passport bros. He felt he was entitled to her because she was a woman and on top of that, one he "imported" from the third world. author: @pisceanbeauty2503
text: Great explanation. Too many people think about crime from a punitive standpoint versus prevention. Our criminal justice system monetizes the punishment process and delegitimizes the prevention efforts that actually reduce crime. So much about the system actually encourages recidivism (not by mistake).

author: @joywagner979
text:
Some dudes sympathize with guys like Ali because "women! What can we men do when we end up in relationships we don't enjoy, when we hate being alone?!?"

Uh, well, maybe work on that last part first? Don't treat women like Ali treated Ana, second? And third, when you're in a relationship you don't enjoy because you feel the woman is spending too much of your money or you think she's cheating? Leave. Find someone you can trust more and who lives like you want. 

"But I can't trust any woman!"
That's a you problem. Try cognitive behavioral therapy and hanging out with emotionally mature, trustworthy women who share your personal values.
"But she'll take half my stuff and never let me see my kids!"
Leave before you have kids. Ideally, leave before you get married. Don't get married and have kids with women you don't trust or know or even like.
"But she hits me!"
That sucks. No one should hit anyone else. Leave after the first time she hits you. 

This is the type of advice that type of dude gives to women in Ana's position, so I honestly don't understand why they can't follow the same advice themselves.
And if a woman treated a man like Ali treated Ana, I would advise the woman to stop that behavior or leave the relationship and the man to run as soon as possible, too. So that's not a double standard. None of his behavior was acceptable for anyone and nobody deserved to be subjected to all that.

author: @NaritaZaraki
text:
I love love love you taking contemporary true crime content as a springboard to talk about movements and strategies to ACTUALLY address their underlying causes! While True Crime content definitely doesn't leave its audience with a great view of the criminal justice system with a million examples of police systemic failure and corruption, the narrative structure and limited scope of engagement with the wider political systems of our societies, unfortunately, only leaves the audience with impotent rage that is easily coopted by "tough on crime", "carceral feminism", and/or some narrow "reformist" vision for a better future. Cutting through the heart of all that like you just did is so vital! 

I really needed this today. And I know that there will be other days when patriarchal violence with have me seeing red and wanting to reach for the "solutions" that can only inflict the most pain, and I will need this compassionate nudge again. Thank you.

author: @MadamKaiju

author: @kylaevelyn1800
text: I really appreciate this discussion. I always felt that the thing stopping me from being fully on board with abolition were the mechanisms and systems that lead to violence OUTSIDE of poverty and marginalization ("affluenza", misogyny, racism and xenophobia, homophobia and transphobia etc.). Like, I get that investing into social programs that actually address material concerns and address the root causes of crime is the more effective and compassionate option, but that doesn't really address the crimes of people who don't fall into those categories, but who's fundamental beliefs justify their violence towards others. To be clear, I was already like 95% of the way there, this just helps with that last 5% lol

author: @courtneybermack
text:
I think that we feel it's somehow easier to correct poverty than entitlement, partner violence, sexual violence, etc. it's all tied together, you can't end any of them without the others and progress on any helps the others... 

But when people think allegations of cheating justify murder if the victim is an immigrant woman of color, it's hard to move that needle. 

You keep emphasizing that she wasn't even the cheater, as if that matters! She could be out with every man and woman in town and it still wouldn't justify murder. But we still have to emphasize that, to show she's one of the good women.

author: @sr350ncb
text:
cases like this make me so angry, even if she did cheat how the fuck would that justify taking her life and the life of who you suspected she cheated with? 

recently i was at an event and i was sitting chatting with some dudes my age and one asked what they would do if theoretically they found their girl cheating on them. most of them said they would catch a case, and although they said it somewhat jokingly i still fear that type of mentality that a lot of dudes and more rarely women have that they would feel justified in taking someones life if that happened.

ik this is not 100% pertinent to the video as this was specifically this man believing his ex cheated on him and killing her over the shit he internalized, but the normalization of escalating romantic betrayal, or percieved romantic betrayal to murder is so insane to me. its sickening how many people would defend it saying oh they did all this for their partner, they were together for X years. people who think like that are not very adjusted at all.

again this is not counting rejection, honor killing, breaking up, etc. which is its own fucked up thing. im specifically talking about cheating. like your life is not some fucking shakespearean drama, go get therapy.

edit: sry for the rant, i had to get this out üòì

author: @roseberkman
text:
As a gender-based violence victim advocate who also dreams of abolition: THANK YOU! You've laid it out perfectly. I see my clients want more restorative practices for the people who harmed them, like counseling and education, and the system isn't capable of providing that. They speak up because they don't want someone else to be harmed the way they were but that voice is not always listened to. I feel like I'm talking to a brick wall when I want to do more work with our incoming students (I'm campus based) on consent and healthy relationships. Or to get more men involved in doing that work so it's not just me talking at them. 

It's a weird place to be in because I know I work within a system that continues to do harm even if I try to mitigate it. I want to do away with punitive responses, but I feel a sense of relief and accomplishment when someone who hurt my clients finally faces consequences.

author: @ChristopherSadlowski

I might have trouble distancing myself enough from these stories to look at them analytically. Thanks for being able to do this kind of work. It must be...hurtful?...to be knee deep in this stuff all the time.

author: @inaruboricua
text: All you say makes sense. There are also extremely violent women because yes, one is taught that violence is normal. I don't think a militaristic society that glorifies violence can ever be abolitionist. It will always glorify violence as the ultimate solution so it dehumanizes the victim and perpetrator. I see women who adore the military mindset, the thug mindset, the brutal mom/sis/daughter/auntie/grandma/niece/whatever mindset, and it is all taught. It's hard to teach peace. That turn the other cheek thing is seen as so holy because it doesn't feel human, humanly possible. But of course it is. Resorting to violence never really makes the winner feel good, never mind the recipient. I mean it does for a second, then the consequences come. What we should be taught is how to disable anyone assaulting us, with whatever is available, and leave it at that. But anyone beaten hand-to-hand can now just be shot. We're kinda screwed. We're too irresponsible and immature for the weapons we invented.

author: @PettiBetti
text: I completely agree. I really thought the gang thing in prison was a myth but then I went to rehab (deep in Bk) and a lot of the men around me had been through the system and many had gang tattoos but had no ideological affiliations; they got tatted because it was about survival. I spoke with them and the general thought was prison makes a criminal out of people who would‚Äôve otherwise never been criminals because they hook up with other big time criminals and instead of rehabilitation they get indoctrinated.

author: @philipbeadle6446
text: While we're talking nuance, I call myself a revolutionary socialist rather than an abolitionist because I believe abolishing institutions such as prisons and policing will require fundamentally replacing the system those institutions serve. I agree infrastructure changes and police/prison reforms are important steps towards that goal, but I dont think capitalism can remain and not require some kind of violent institutions to uphold it.

author: @felix_forrester
text: I respect the fundamentals of abolition but it's just so intensely utopian in a way that feels impossible to implement without a thousand years of concerted effort across the whole planet. Even if we reshape all of civilization to 100% account for all society's systemic failings, people won't just be uniformly "good". People will still do horrific things and require separation from the rest of society regardless of how many others are successfully mitigated. This man *maybe* could have been prevented. It will always be a *maybe*, there's no way to predict something like that, only ways to predict lowering the chance.
